topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on Anthropic’s extreme AI-assisted coding rates and how Claude Code is built using Claude itself. Lenny introduces Mike Krieger (Anthropic CPO, Instagram co-founder) and previews major topics for the episode.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Productboard and Stripe, including Productboard Pulse (VoC + AI analysis) and Stripe’s scale and AI-driven payments optimization.

topics.title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
topics.summary: Mike describes two major belief updates: faster-than-expected timelines and a leap in model creativity/novelty of thought. He cites Opus 4 as a turning point where Claude became a genuinely useful strategy partner with new angles, not just generic feedback.

topics.title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
topics.summary: Prompted by AI 2027, they discuss risk and how to steer outcomes toward “going well.” Mike explains joining Anthropic to maximize positive influence on human–AI relationships via product, research, and interpretability work.

topics.title: Raising kids in an AI world
topics.summary: Mike shares how he encourages curiosity, inquiry, and independent thinking rather than defaulting to “ask Claude.” He emphasizes maintaining confidence and scientific discovery habits even with powerful AI tools.

topics.title: When 90% of code is AI-written
topics.summary: They unpack how product development changes when AI writes most code: faster prototyping by PMs/designers, but new bottlenecks in alignment/decision-making and operational flow (merge queues, coordination). Mike frames it as discovering new constraints in the system’s critical path.

topics.title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
topics.summary: Mike explains how the Claude Code team uses Claude Code to build Claude Code, changing review practices (more acceptance testing, AI-assisted review) and enabling contributions from non-TypeScript engineers. He estimates Claude Code may be 95%+ AI-generated and highlights lowered barriers to entry.

topics.title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
topics.summary: They discuss using AI to identify user pain points, propose solutions, and even generate PRs and experiments quickly. Mike points to MCP and better context flow as key enablers for turning community feedback into code changes and A/B tests.

topics.title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
topics.summary: Referencing the OpenAI/Anthropic panel, Mike reiterates that embedding PMs with research/post-training yields the most leverage versus only polishing UX. He uses Artifacts as an example of product + post-training collaboration producing differentiated experiences.

topics.title: Where product value remains in the AI era
topics.summary: Mike argues product’s enduring value is making capabilities comprehensible, setting strategy (where to play/how to win), and revealing what’s possible to customers. He describes a large “overhang” between what models can do and how most people use them today.

topics.title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
topics.summary: Mike shares practical prompting patterns: explicitly ask Claude to “think hard,” request harsher critique (“roast this”), and use the Console’s prompt improver to generate structured prompts (e.g., XML tags) that outperform intuition. He notes Claude is often the best prompter of Claude.

topics.title: Rick Rubin collaboration and “vibe coding”
topics.summary: Mike explains the origin of Anthropic’s Rick Rubin collaboration via Jack Clark and Rubin’s interest in AI, creativity, and coding. They describe it as a meditation on creating alongside AI with distinctive ASCII-art aesthetics.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor segment with OneSchema describing FileFeeds 2.0 for AI-assisted spreadsheet/CSV intake, validation, and integrations (SFTP/S3/email).

topics.title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
topics.summary: Mike recounts being approached by longtime friend Joel Lewenstein after Artifact, meeting Anthropic leadership, and being drawn to the company’s intellectual honesty and responsible AI stance. He reflects on onboarding, moving too slowly on some org changes, and the outsized impact of a few “founder-type” engineers (e.g., Claude Code’s origins).

topics.title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
topics.summary: Mike explains Artifact’s headwinds: deteriorating mobile web UX/ads, limited organic sharing dynamics for personalized news, and the difficulty of making major strategic shifts while fully remote. He discusses opportunity cost as AI accelerated, and the emotional/ego aspects of shutting down a well-liked product despite insufficient growth.
